text: Hey, it's Anthony Ramos from GLAAD.
And guess what?
We have got a brand new
reimagined version of Queer as Folk,

which will be available
 starting June 9th on Peacock.

And today,
 I'm so excited to be chatting

with the cast
 and the creative team.

First up,
 let's say hello to the creator,

the writer, the executive producer
 and the director, Stephen Dunn.

Next,
 we have the executive producer
and writer Jaclyn Moore.
Now to the cast.
We have Devin Way, who plays Brodie.
Fin Argus plays Mingus.
Jesse James Keitel plays Ruthie.
CG plays Shar.
Johnny Sibilly plays Noah.
And Ryan O'Connell plays Julian.

I would love to hear from you,
 Stephen, just what
that original series meant to you.

I mean, I used to watch it
 in my basement

with the volume turned down
 super low with the,

like, last channel button
 ready to flip back to YTV.
And like, I was watching it, like,
with bated breath.
Like, it was my sexual awakening.

It was my first exposure
 to a queer community.

When I saw the British series,
 it was just so punk.
It was vibrant.

These characters
 just like leapt off the screen.

And it was
 a very meaningful experience,

like seeing that show
 at such a young age.
And really,
I think it changed the landscape

of television, of queer
 storytelling.
I completely agree.

being so afraid of
 someone saw me watching it.

You know,
 I think thinking about the

the original version of Queer as Folk,

about trans people,

Yeah,
 I mean, it means everything, right?

want to express ourselves,

And so to have this opportunity
 to just speak

very honestly and truthfully,

than what queerness meant publicly

you know,
 maybe a little more honest

 Am I still like the partyer?

 how are you, Ryan?

about a group of friends,
 it actually touches on
siblings, which I love.

 relationship.

 I'd love for you to kind of explain

Yeah, like Julian

 issues.

both of them
 are kind of loath to admit,

It's definitely
 a little twisted sister.
Jaclyn, let's go back to you.

I think, you know, thinking

and how we say it's

so important that we are
 stories are told by queer people.

And I know it was so intentional
 for all of you
to really have queer people

 writers in all parts of creating.

Tell me about that

it was obviously I know
 it was such a priority for you.
It's important to tell honest
stories and representation
on its own only takes you

so far, and especially
 when that representation is through

maybe a cis white straight
 male often lens
that is not really interested
in telling like true stories of,

you know, trans people or queer

like sort of, you know, oh,
 no, look , we have a trans person.

Oh, look,
 we have some queer people.

And as a result, you end up

and you end up with, to be honest,
 I think, representation that feels
a little toothless to me.

And I think with the show
 something was very important to us,

was wanting to go beyond that,
 that like simply representing

our, you know, communities wasn't
 enough.

It's about being, allowing us
 to be seen on

queer people, trans people,
 to be seen as messy.
Creating stories

that live in sort of a messy
 middle is what we wanted to do.

And allowing us
 the dignity of what, to be honest,
like straight white guys

and other groups are starting
 to get to see all the time.

I think one of my favorite moments
 in the writers room

was actually when our
 writers assistant, Alissa Taylor,
came out to the room as straight,
which was just like,

yes, it was like
 incredibly charming.
It was a very sweet moment.

But then like after we finished

And it really hit me like,
 I think this is the first work

environment I've ever been in
 that was really, really queer.

It made us realize that like,
 this is a really special

environment and we are really kind
 of we're making a show

that I think can only be told
 from this community.

And I'm really proud of this,
 like, team of Avengers

that we've assembled, both in

Because the show itself, I think

the queerness of the show
 is baked into its DNA.

It's in every fiber 
of its creation.
It's important to talk about that

the series definitely does
 focus on tragedy.

And I think there's, from the get
 go, we see that there's a storyline

that is definitely inspired
 by the Pulse nightclub

shooting tragedy that happened,
 you know, in real life.
And I know

you all worked closely
 with some of the Pulse survivors.

Tell me why it was important
 for you to kind of go that route
when creating the series?
Yeah, of course.

I mean, first of all,
 I mean, the events in our show

are fictional
 and although they are heavily

inspired by the events
 that happened in Orlando at the
The Pulse nightclub shooting,

which really was specifically
 targeting the queer

Latinx community,
 I traveled to Orlando

after getting the rights
 from Russell, who saw this as the

as the way to expand
 upon the legacy of the show.
And I met with the survivors
thanks to Joel Morales

and the Orlando United
 Assistance Center,
I set up roundtables

and individual interviews
 to really understand

not just that night,
 but who they were before

and who they are,
 who they were after

and the way in which that night
 impacted them

in the long term, not just like,
 you know, our show doesn't center.
It's not a show about a shooting.

It's a show about about
 the rebuilding of a community.

And it's specifically
 about how a community rebuilds

in the wake of a tragedy like this
 to create a bigger, better, safer

space that's more
 inclusive than the one before it.
And that's what I saw

in Orlando, what I learned
 from those survivors.

And so we engaged with
 the survivors, and we continued to

hire those who were interested
 as consultants on the show

to make sure that we were
 really getting the story right,

that we were that
 we were doing it justice.

Queer joy doesn't exist in a world
 without trauma.

Like, to be queer,
 to be trans in America
in 2022 is to face trauma a lot.
And it's from that trauma

that queer joy always comes from,
 because that's what queerness is.
It's defiance of trauma.

It's defiance of a world
 that doesn't always want you there.

And I think specifically, the idea

about a community coming together
and finding queer joy.
